question.text: You should___with your boss before committing yourself to that project.

answer.explanation: (B) The modal “should” is followed by the base form of the verb. Choice (A) is future tense. Choice (C) is present participle or a gerund. Choice (D) is past participle.

question.text: The meeting will take place tomorrow from 10:00___11:00.

answer.explanation: (B) Time expressions with “from . . . to” tell when an event begins and ends. Choices (A), (C), and (D) are not used in expressions with from.
(B) “Tasks” must be modified by an adjective. Choice (A) is a verb. Choice (C) is a noun. Choice (D) is an adverb.
(C) The costs are rising themselves; use the present participle. Choices (A) and (D) must tell who raised costs. Choice (B) is the past participle.

question.text: The ___ about our recycling plans will reassure consumers.

answer.explanation: (D) The sentence requires a noun subject. Choice (A) is a noun but is not logical. Choice (B) is a verb. Choice (C) is a gerund.

question.text: The auditor discovered that the accountant had not been ___ the checks into the correct account.

answer.explanation: (D) The past progressive “had not been” requires the -ing form “depositing” to complete it. Choice (A) is the past tense. Choice (B) is the present tense. Choice (C) is the simple form.

question.text: Visitors are reminded ___ name tags at all times.

answer.explanation: (A) “Reminded” requires the infinitive. Choice (B) is the simple form. Choice (C) is the past participle. Choice (D) is the progressive form.
(B)The verb “expect” is followed by an infinitive verb. Choice (A) is base form or present tense. Choice (C) is present participle or a gerund. Choice (D) is future tense.
(B) “Always” goes between the auxiliary verb and the main verb. In Choice (C) “always” is before the auxiliary verb. In choices (A) and (D) always is after the main verb.

question.text: At the end of the year, the company puts ___ a picnic for the employees.

answer.explanation: (D) “Put on” is a two-word verb that in this context means to “produce”. The other prepositions in Choices (A), (B), and (C) do not fit the context of the sentence.
